Her mother, however, seemed entirely captivated by Mr. Gable’s very seriousness, mistaking his lack of animation for a sign of profound character, and pressing the matter with an insistence that quite put Eleanor out of countenance.  It was a vexing thing, to have one’s own happiness so earnestly, yet so mistakenly, pursued by those one most wished to please.

It was a truth universally acknowledged, though perhaps not yet universally acted upon with due prudence, that a young lady in possession of a tolerable fortune and a pleasing countenance must be in want of a suitable establishment. Miss Eleanor Ainsworth, though possessed of neither fortune nor, in her own estimation, any particular claim to beauty, found herself the object of a most unexpected, and to her, quite bewildering, degree of attention. Her aunt, Mrs. Davies, a woman of considerable influence and even more considerable opinion, had lately taken to remarking upon the lamentable state of spinsterhood with a vehemence that suggested a personal affront, and had begun to cast her astute gaze upon every gentleman of a certain age and income who happened to cross their path, much to Eleanor's quiet exasperation.

The recent engagement of Miss Eliza Davenport to Mr. Silas Thorne, though a matter of considerable speculation amongst the more discerning members of Meryton society, seemed to cause a peculiar lack of outward joy within the Davenport household itself, a circumstance that did not escape Mrs. Bennet’s ever-watchful eye. While Eliza herself presented a countenance of dutiful contentment, a closer observer might have detected a certain lack of sparkle, a subtle restraint that hinted at obligations fulfilled rather than desires ardently pursued. Her mother, however, was entirely satisfied, seeing in Mr. Thorne a gentleman of good fortune and respectable connexions, whose ample estate at Netherfield offered the very security she so desperately sought for her brood of daughters, a prospect far more agreeable than the endless anxieties of securing advantageous marriages for those less fortunate.

The news of Mr. Collins's impending marriage to Charlotte Lucas, whilst met with a resigned sigh from Mrs. Bennet and a decidedly less charitable one from Elizabeth, did not, however, diminish the keen interest that the subject of *matrimony* invariably excited within the drawing-rooms of Hertfordshire. For, as every sensible person knew, a woman's prospects, particularly those of limited fortune, were inextricably tied to the altar, and any discourse upon suitable connections, or indeed, the lack thereof, occupied the minds of both mothers and daughters with an urgency that bordered on the obsessive. The arrival of Mr. Bingley’s party at Netherfield, therefore, was not merely a social event; it was a beacon of hope, a potential salvation from the dreaded ignominy of spinsterhood, and the cause for much fluttering amongst the local gentry, all eager to discern which of their eligible daughters might catch the discerning eye of the wealthy and amiable newcomer.

The evening had progressed with the usual gentle hum of polite conversation, punctuated by the occasional discreet sigh from Mrs. Bennet, whose hopes, it seemed, rested entirely upon the attentions of any gentleman who possessed not merely a respectable fortune, but also a remarkable degree of patience. Mr. Collins, ever attentive to his own consequence, had spent a considerable portion of the hour detailing the virtues of his patroness, Lady Catherine de Bourgh, much to the quiet amusement of Mr. Darcy, who surveyed the scene with an air of dispassionate curiosity, as if observing a particularly amusing specimen of natural history. Meanwhile, Elizabeth, though outwardly engaged in a discussion concerning the merits of watercolour versus oils, found her thoughts frequently straying to the peculiar machinations of her mother’s matchmaking endeavours, and the often-unforeseen consequences that arose from such well-intentioned, yet frequently misguided, efforts.

It was, of course, a matter of considerable speculation amongst the neighbourhood that Miss Eleanor Ainsworth, possessed of a respectable, if not precisely opulent, fortune, and a disposition to be exceedingly obliging, should at last be taken into consideration by Mr. Davies, whose estate, though somewhat encumbered by the vagaries of his late uncle's investments, still offered a prospect of comfortable independence.  Her mother, Lady Ainsworth, having long lamented Eleanor’s quiet demurral to the more boisterous attentions of younger gentlemen, saw in Mr. Davies’s measured gallantry and grave pronouncements a most suitable alliance, a notion Eleanor herself could not entirely dismiss, though the thought of domestic management, even with the assistance of a good housekeeper, did occasion a certain mild disquiet in her usually serene breast.

Lady Ashworth, though possessed of a perfectly respectable fortune and a countenance not entirely devoid of pleasing regularity, found herself increasingly vexed by the attentions of Mr. Silas Bramwell. His conversation, though seldom entirely without sense, was invariably prefaced with so many elaborate compliments that one quite lost the thread of his actual meaning. He spoke of her eyes with a fervour that suggested he had never before encountered a pair of blue irises, and her wit, when it did manage to escape her lips unbidden, was lauded as if it were the sole possession of such quality in all of Hertfordshire. Her mother, naturally, saw only the undeniable advantage of his landed estate and the convenient proximity of his paternal home, a prospect that rendered all other considerations, however pertinent to the young lady's own happiness, entirely secondary.

It was a truth universally acknowledged that a gentleman in possession of a good fortune must be in want of a wife, though Miss Eleanor Dashwood, at present residing with her sensible Aunt Jennings, found herself quite indifferent to such universal truths, or indeed to any gentleman at all, beyond the agreeable contemplation of his character and fortune, should such contemplation prove beneficial to her dearest sister. Her aunt, a lady of considerable experience in the matrimonial market, had, with characteristic good nature and a decided lack of subtlety, begun to sound out the merits of Mr. Willoughby, a gentleman of handsome countenance and decidedly engaging manners, whose attentions to Marianne had been, in her opinion, far too pronounced to be entirely innocent, and certainly too encouraging to be easily dismissed, though Eleanor, with a wisdom beyond her years, could perceive the delicate balance of prudence and passion that must inevitably guide such nascent affections.

It was, therefore, with a mixture of resigned duty and a faint flutter of curiosity that Miss Eleanor Dashwood found herself accompanying her mother and sisters to the annual county ball, an occasion which, in the opinion of many a sensible matron, served as the principal market for matrimonial acquisitions. Her younger sister Marianne, bless her impetuous heart, was already engaged in animated discourse with a gentleman whose countenance, whilst not displeasing, lacked the intellectual spark that Eleanor so valued; a common failing, she mused, amongst those whose principal recommendation was a comfortable estate. Meanwhile, Mrs. Dashwood, ever the optimist, cast a hopeful glance towards the eligible bachelors, no doubt calculating the most advantageous alliances with the same meticulousness she employed in the management of their modest household.

The arrival of Mr. Willoughby at Pemberley, though a subject of much excited conjecture amongst the neighbours, had brought with it an almost palpable air of consequence to the usually placid routine of the estate. Elizabeth, observing him from her dressing-room window, could not but reflect upon the peculiar manner in which Providence seemed to orchestrate the comings and goings of men. Here was a gentleman whose fortunes, though lately less brilliant than once promised, still held sufficient lustre to attract the attention of every discerning eye, and whose presence, it was whispered, had already quite captivated the affections of more than one young lady of respectable connection. Yet, as she watched him converse with Darcy, a shade of something unreadable crossing his countenance, she wondered if the outward show of gaiety concealed a more troubled spirit, or if, as was more often the case, the world merely chose to interpret as profound what was, in truth, merely the common anxieties of a man in society.

It was not merely the prospect of his considerable fortune, though that certainly played its part, that drew Miss Eleanor Ainsworth's attention to Mr. Silas Croft. Indeed, his countenance possessed a certain regularity, and his conversation, while rarely sparkling, was seldom disagreeable, qualities that, in the eyes of many a discerning young lady, might well compensate for a lack of ardent affection. Yet, it was the unmistakable favour with which his mother regarded Eleanor, a woman whose opinion carried no small weight in their small circle, that truly cemented the alliance. For what good is a suitor, however amiable, if his family's approval is wanting? Such considerations, whispered Mrs. Ainsworth to her favourite daughter with a knowing wink, are of the utmost consequence when navigating the delicate pathways of matrimony and securing a respectable future.

It was with a mixture of resigned duty and a flicker of hopeful, though often disappointed, expectation that Miss Eleanor Dashwood surveyed the assembly at Netherfield. Her younger sister, Marianne, ever the enthusiast, was already engaged in a spirited discussion with Mr. Willoughby on the merits of various poetical passages, a conversation which, Eleanor shrewdly observed, seemed to hold more interest for Marianne than for the gentleman in question, whose eyes frequently strayed towards the lady of the house, the amiable Miss Bingley. Eleanor could not but reflect upon the singular folly of young ladies who, in their eagerness to secure advantageous connections, often overlooked the subtle yet significant indications of indifference, preferring instead to build their castles in the air upon the shifting sands of present admiration, a construction doomed, in her experience, to a most disagreeable collapse.

It was with a mixture of resignation and a certain, albeit faint, flicker of curiosity that Miss Eleanor Ainsworth found herself once again contemplating the eligible gentlemen presented at the autumnal assembly. The season, though not yet at its height, had already produced a respectable number of candidates for matrimonial consideration, each boasting a degree of fortune and, it was generally assumed, a sufficiency of amiable disposition. Her mother, ever vigilant in the discharge of her maternal duties, had made it abundantly clear that a prudent match was not merely desirable, but essential for the family’s continued comfort, a sentiment Eleanor understood with the wearisome clarity of one who had heard it echoed through many a drawing-room conversation. Yet, as she observed Mr. Davies, a gentleman of considerable property but possessing a countenance more suited to the study of ledgers than the exchange of pleasantries, she could not help but feel that her own understanding of happiness might, alas, diverge rather inconveniently from the path of pragmatic arrangement.

It was a truth universally acknowledged, though perhaps not yet universally acted upon, that a young lady in possession of a tolerable fortune and an agreeable countenance, must be in want of a husband. Miss Eleanor Ainsworth, at four and twenty, found herself firmly entrenched in this category, much to the mingled concern and amusement of her dear Mama, whose own matrimonial triumphs, though distant, still coloured her every waking thought. While Eleanor privately harboured a quiet contentment with her books and her needlework, her mother’s pronouncements on eligible gentlemen and the urgent necessity of securing an establishment were as regular as the changing of the seasons, each one accompanied by a gentle sigh and the rustle of silk, leaving Eleanor to wonder if perhaps her independence was, in fact, a rather unfashionable impediment.

It was, however, a truth universally acknowledged, though perhaps not always readily admitted by those most intimately concerned, that a young lady of fortune, however modest, could scarcely be too well-provided for in the matter of eligible admirers. Miss Eleanor Ainsworth, possessed of a comfortable jointure from her late aunt and a disposition inclined neither towards excessive gaiety nor indeed much spirited conversation, found herself, to her mother’s considerable relief, the object of no fewer than two gentlemen’s attentions. One, a Captain Davies, whose naval exploits were doubtless the stuff of legend, albeit largely unheard by those not privy to his barracks gossip, offered a prospect of stable, if somewhat prosaic, domesticity. The other, a Mr. Silas Croft, whose income, while respectable, was rumoured to be less secure than his manners were assured, presented a more romantic, if potentially precarious, entanglement. Mrs. Ainsworth, naturally, viewed both with a judicious eye, weighing the merits of each against the imperative of securing her daughter’s future, and, by extension, her own peace of mind.

The prospect of another Season, though approaching with its usual admixture of gaiety and obligation, had begun to weigh upon Miss Eleanor Ainsworth with a distinct lack of enthusiasm. Her mother, Mrs. Ainsworth, was, as ever, possessed of the firmest convictions regarding the necessity of a suitable match for her eldest daughter, and had already begun to itemise the eligible gentlemen of the neighbourhood with the precision of a seasoned strategist. Eleanor, meanwhile, found herself increasingly drawn to the quiet contemplation of her books and the gentle ministrations of her garden, pursuits which, she suspected, offered far more enduring satisfaction than the fleeting attentions of any gentleman with merely a tolerable estate and a modicum of politeness. The very idea of parading oneself for inspection, of engaging in conversations designed solely to impress, struck her as a most tiresome expenditure of one's precious time and spirit.

Miss Eleanor Ainsworth, though possessed of a tolerable fortune and an agreeable countenance, found herself in a most vexing predicament; her mother, Lady Ainsworth, was entirely set upon her marrying Mr. Fitzwilliam, a gentleman whose chief attractions lay in his three thousand a year and a decidedly indifferent conversation. Eleanor, however, harboured a quiet preference for the younger Mr. Ashworth, a curate of modest means but possessing a wit that sparkled like fine champagne and a heart that seemed to beat in unison with her own. The pressure from home was considerable, for Lady Ainsworth saw in Mr. Fitzwilliam the perfect solution to their somewhat reduced circumstances, and Eleanor, bound by filial duty, felt the weight of her mother's expectations pressing upon her youthful inclinations, a common affliction amongst sensible young ladies of good breeding.

It was with a sigh, not entirely of resignation, that Miss Eleanor Dashwood surveyed the pile of sewing intended to furnish her sister Marianne’s trousseau. To be sure, Edward Ferrars’s attachment was the object of universal admiration and, indeed, of Marianne’s most ardent affections; yet, the practicalities of their impending union, however delightful in prospect, fell with predictable weight upon the shoulders of the more sensible sister. One could not but observe how swiftly the glow of romantic attachment often cast a shadow of domestic duty upon those less inclined to dreamy contemplation. Whilst Marianne discoursed on the sublime beauty of their future life, Eleanor found herself contemplating the precise number of pillowcases requisite for a respectable establishment, a concern, she mused wryly, that even the most impassioned declarations could not entirely dismiss.

It was, of course, quite expected that the arrival of Mr. Fitzwilliam Darcy at Pemberley would occasion a considerable stir amongst the neighbours, particularly those young ladies whose mothers had long since begun to calculate the advantages of such a connection. Miss Bingley, whose own prospects had unfortunately narrowed with the departure of her brother from Netherfield, found herself quite disinclined to acknowledge any merit in Mrs. Darcy's supposed good fortune, and was observed to make frequent, disparaging remarks regarding the gentleman's rumoured reserve. Yet, even she could not entirely conceal her envy when informed that the master of Pemberley, despite his well-known fastidiousness, had recently exhibited a decided partiality for the society of his wife's less wealthy, and indeed less distinguished, relations, a circumstance that spoke volumes of his character, and, as some might observe, of hers as well.

Miss Eleanor Ainsworth, a young woman possessed of a sensible mind and a tolerable fortune, found herself in the rather tiresome position of being courted by Mr. Thorne, a gentleman whose chief recommendation was his unwavering, albeit tedious, affection. Her mother, of course, saw in him a most eligible match, a prospect that filled Eleanor’s own breast with a mixture of resignation and a desire for a more stimulating companionship than a man whose conversation rarely strayed beyond the weather and the latest county gossip. To be sure, Mr. Thorne was not without his merits; he was neither dissolute nor demonstrative in any alarming fashion, and he owned a respectable estate that would, in time, ensure a comfortable establishment. Yet, Eleanor could not quite reconcile her own quietly spirited inclinations with the prospect of a lifetime spent in such amiable, yet uninspired, domesticity.

The evening had, alas, concluded with a civility that bordered on the insipid, leaving Miss Eliza decidedly unimpressed with the prospects of acquaintance with the accomplished Mr. Davies. He possessed, to be sure, a tolerable fortune and a countenance not wholly disagreeable, yet his conversation, whilst perfectly proper, lacked any spark of true wit or genuine feeling. Indeed, his discourse had been chiefly occupied with the price of good wool and the regrettable decline of sensible tailoring amongst the younger gentlemen, a topic of little consequence to a lady who concerned herself far more with the quality of a man's affections than the cut of his coat. Her aunt, however, whose own marital bliss had been a model of quiet contentment rather than passionate ardour, had pronounced him a most eligible prospect, hinting broadly at the advantages of a settlement secured before the capricious winds of affection could shift to less practical shores.

The evening’s entertainment having run its course, and the last of the lukewarm tea having been politely refused, Mrs. Bennet found herself in a most unenviable predicament. Young Mr. Collins, bless his pompous heart, seemed as determined to linger as a debt collector, and Elizabeth, whose spirits had been sorely tested by his protracted pronouncements on his patroness, now eyed the door with an impatience barely concealed by the veneer of good breeding. To her mother, however, this was not an occasion for relief, but a fresh spur to action; for a gentleman of property, however tiresome, was not to be lightly dismissed, particularly when the alternative was the continued guardianship of five daughters whose prospects grew dimmer with each passing season, a truth that weighed upon her maternal bosom with a decidedly unromantic heaviness.

It was with a mixture of relief and a certain, perhaps uncharitable, anticipation that Mrs. Bennet at last beheld her eldest daughter, Jane, safely ensconced at Netherfield Park. The prospect of Mr. Bingley's affections being so plainly declared, and his intentions so honourably presented, had considerably eased the domestic tensions that had lately threatened to overwhelm her. Indeed, the prospect of one daughter well-provided for, with the agreeable appendage of a respectable fortune, did much to soften the imagined hardships of securing advantageous matches for the remaining four. Yet, even as she congratulated herself on this singular triumph, a nagging whisper of disquiet began to surface; for whilst Jane might now be sheltered from the immediate anxieties of want, the peculiar nature of Mr. Bingley’s attentions, so readily swayed by the opinions of his sisters, offered a subtle but persistent cause for concern, hinting at a future not entirely devoid of its own peculiar trials.

It was a truth universally acknowledged, at least within the confines of the Elmwood estate, that Miss Eleanor Ainsworth possessed a disposition as amiable as it was unfortunately dependent upon the caprices of her elder sister. While Marianne, bless her impetuous heart, flitted from one romantic entanglement to another with the reckless abandon of a butterfly, Eleanor found herself perpetually tethered to the quieter duties of domesticity and the rather more pressing concern of her brother’s imminent inheritance. The arrival of Mr. Harrington, a gentleman of impeccable pedigree and a fortune that could surely ease their collective anxieties, had therefore occasioned a flutter of polite expectation, though Eleanor herself, ever the pragmatist, reserved her judgement, observing the subtle negotiations of courtship with a keen, though outwardly demure, eye.

Mr. Dashwood, a man whose fortune, though respectable, was by no means of that magnitude to allow for idle expenditure, felt a considerable degree of anxiety concerning the future establishment of his three daughters. Their mother, a woman whose amiable disposition was unfortunately allied with a decided want of prudence, seemed wholly unconcerned with the necessity of making advantageous matches, placing her affections, with a distressing uniformity, upon any gentleman who possessed the slightest acquaintance with them. It was to his eldest, Elinor, a young woman of uncommon sense and steadiness, that he confided his deepest reservations, for he knew that while Marianne’s impassioned declarations of love might capture a poet’s fancy, it was Elinor’s quiet good judgment that would secure a comfortable establishment and the approval of sensible relations.

It was, to be sure, a matter of some consternation that Miss Eleanor Ashworth, possessed of neither striking beauty nor a fortune to ignite the most jaded of imaginations, found herself the object of Mr. Thomas Sterling’s attentions.  Her mother, whose every waking thought seemed bent upon securing advantageous settlements for her three daughters, declared it a most propitious turn of events, conveniently overlooking the gentleman's notorious parsimony and rather dull conversation.  Eleanor, meanwhile, could not entirely suppress a sigh when Mr. Sterling, with a most earnest and rather alarming gravity, began to detail the precise cost of his estate's latest repairs, a topic that promised to dominate their courtship with a thrilling lack of romance, but an abundance of fiscal responsibility, which, as her mother often reminded her, was the very foundation of a sensible union.

The arrival of Mr. Darcy at Netherfield, a circumstance which had occasioned such a flutter amongst the younger ladies of Meryton, now seemed to promise an entirely different sort of consequence. While Elizabeth Bennet, with her characteristic discernment, had found his demeanour to be insufferably proud, and his fortune, though considerable, hardly a sufficient recompense for such an alliance, her mother harboured a more pragmatic, if less agreeable, estimation. Mrs. Bennet, whose chiefest anxiety was the perpetual provision for her five daughters, viewed Mr. Darcy’s acquaintance with Mr. Bingley as a most fortunate conjunction, a prospect that might at last relieve her from the constant specter of the entail. Indeed, she confided in Jane, with a sigh that was not entirely without its satisfaction, that a gentleman of such consequence would surely be the means of securing their future, a sentiment which, whilst perhaps lacking in sentiment, was undeniably sensible in its own peculiar way.

It was, as Mrs. Bennet so frequently declared, a matter of great consequence that her youngest daughters should be settled in life with respectable connections, and as such, a proposal from the estimable Mr. Collins, though perhaps lacking the dazzling brilliance of a Willoughby or the fortune of a Bingley, was deemed by her to be a most fortunate circumstance, indeed. Mr. Collins himself, whilst perhaps more prone to pronouncements of duty and obligation than professions of ardent affection, possessed a comfortable living and a decidedly docile temperament, qualities which, in the eyes of a mother solicitous for her progeny's future, far outweighed the need for an inconveniently passionate attachment. Miss Bennet, though privately inclined towards a more spirited suitor, found herself pressed by the undeniable logic of her mother's arguments, a familiar and oft-repeated logic that painted a grim picture of unmarried obscurity should this opportunity be allowed to pass.

The news of Mr. Willoughby’s abrupt departure, though delivered with a certain practised nonchalance by Mrs. Jennings, did not fail to cast a pall over the otherwise cheerful drawing-room at Allenham. Marianne, of course, received it with a storm of injured feeling, quite convinced that his absence was a testament to a perfidy so profound it could only be the work of the most villainous of men. Elinor, however, whilst sharing her sister’s dismay at the loss of a companion so lately esteemed, could not wholly dismiss the more prosaic, if less dramatic, possibility that Mr. Willoughby’s affairs, rather than his character, had dictated the necessity of his hurried journey, a thought that, whilst offering little solace to Marianne, brought a quiet resignation to her own more sober understanding of the world and its often inconvenient realities.

It was, as Mr. Bennet might have observed, a mercy that Mrs. Bennet possessed so little true discernment, for had she possessed the capacity to accurately gauge the moral character of Mr. Wickham, her incessant anxieties might have been amplified to an unbearable degree. As it was, her flitting attentions were easily diverted by the more superficial accomplishments of a gentleman, such as a pleasing countenance and a ready, albeit insincere, compliment. Young Miss Darcy, however, whose judgment was as keen as her fortune was considerable, perceived with an alarming clarity the hollowness beneath the amiable surface, and found herself, with a mixture of dismay and reluctant admiration, observing the young man's progress with a vigilance that bordered on the possessive. Indeed, one might have sworn she was guarding a treasure, rather than merely observing a decidedly unprincipled adventurer.

Indeed, it was a matter of considerable observation for Mrs. Bennet that her eldest daughter, Jane, possessed a degree of amiable disposition that, whilst delightful to behold, often left her vulnerable to the more calculated machinations of less scrupulous individuals. Whilst her younger sisters might engage in witty repartee or shrewd assessments of a gentleman’s prospects, Jane would readily offer the most charitable interpretation of even the most questionable behaviour, a trait which her mother, with a mixture of pride and exasperation, frequently despaired of. One could only hope, she often mused, that such an excess of innate goodness would not prove a serious impediment when a suitable establishment was to be secured, for a man of sense, though charmed by sweetness, would surely require a more discerning eye than Jane was apt to possess.

It was, of course, a matter of the deepest consequence to Mrs. Bennet that her daughters should make advantageous connections; indeed, she had long ago convinced herself that the very existence of their amiable family depended upon such a feat.  Elizabeth, however, possessed a spirit somewhat too independent for her mother’s exacting notions of propriety, and often found herself contemplating the rather lamentable deficiency of discernment displayed by those who presumed to judge a person’s true worth by the outward trappings of fortune.  Whilst Jane, ever the benevolent soul, sought to find merit in all, Elizabeth, with a keen eye for foible and pretension, was rather more inclined to scrutinise the foundations upon which such amiable opinions were built, a habit which, to her mother’s profound vexation, did not always lead to the most agreeable conclusions.

The unfortunate Mr. Ainsworth, whose profession as a man of considerable fortune had hitherto shielded him from any rigorous examination of his moral character, now found himself the subject of much whispered conjecture amongst the neighbourhood. It was universally agreed that his exceedingly amiable disposition, coupled with a ready wit and a countenance which, though not precisely handsome, was pleasingly open, had greatly contributed to his popularity. Yet, when it became known that his generosity was, in fact, more a matter of careless extravagance than true benevolence, and that his amiable disposition frequently concealed a rather indolent disregard for the feelings of others, the esteemed Mr. Ainsworth began to be regarded with a degree of critical observation previously quite unknown to him. Indeed, it appeared that a merely agreeable temper was scarcely sufficient qualification for that genuine personal virtue which the discerning eye so readily seeks.

It was a truth universally acknowledged, though perhaps not by all who professed it with undue vehemence, that a gentleman of modest fortune but excellent connections ought to be received with a certain deference in any society. Mr. Finch, whose estate was respectable though not indeed grand, possessed the advantage of a cousin once removed to a Baronet, a fact he was not at all disinclined to mention, particularly when addressing those he deemed to be his inferiors. His conversation, therefore, often revolved around the peculiar merits of such distant relationships and the consequent obligations of honour and propriety they entailed, a discourse that, whilst intended to impress, frequently succeeded only in revealing the hollowness of his own claims to genuine virtue.

It was, of course, a matter of no small consequence to Mrs. Bennet that her eldest daughters were to be introduced to such a distinguished party, and she flattered herself that their amiable dispositions and pleasing accomplishments would not fail to make a favourable impression. Indeed, Jane, with her sweet temper and uncommon grace, possessed a certain purity of character that seemed to render her impervious to the vulgarity of the world, whilst Elizabeth, though possessed of a sharper wit, was no less admired for her genuine good sense and a spirited independence that, whilst it might occasionally raise an eyebrow in more timid circles, was at heart a testament to her strong moral fibre. Mr. Bennet, observing his wife's animated preparations, could not suppress a quiet smile; he knew well the superficialities that often governed their society, yet he trusted that in his girls, at least, true worth would ultimately shine, unblemished by the fleeting fashions of the day.

It was a matter of no small consequence, of course, that Miss Eleanor Bennet, possessed as she was of an exceedingly sensible disposition, should have found herself so frequently obliged to contemplate the moral character of her acquaintance, particularly when their actions so often presented a less-than-flattering reflection of their supposed virtues. For while some, like her own dear sister Jane, seemed to radiate an almost saintly goodness that could charm the very birds from the trees, others, alas, displayed a more common failing – a tendency to mistake ostentation for true worth, and to believe that a well-turned compliment, or a generous display of plate at dinner, might entirely compensate for a deficiency in genuine principle. Eleanor, with her keen eye and a heart that valued sincerity above all the glittering adornments of society, could not but observe these distinctions with a mixture of amusement and, at times, a quiet disapprobation.

It was with a profound sigh, though outwardly presented as no more than a delicate inclination of the head, that Miss Bennet acknowledged Mr. Collins's latest pronouncement on the matter of his patroness, Lady Catherine de Bourgh's, singular beneficence. Indeed, the gentleman seemed to possess an unshakeable conviction that virtue was a commodity as readily dispensed from the grand estate of Rosings as her ladyship's opinion, and that his own good fortune in securing such a connexion was proof enough of his own inherent, if somewhat overshadowed, merit. Elizabeth, whilst not entirely disbelieving the existence of Lady Catherine's charitable inclinations, could not help but feel a certain amusement at the notion that Mr. Collins, whose own moral compass seemed to veer so wildly between obsequiousness and self-importance, should be so readily appointed as her ladyship's chief interpreter of virtuous conduct. It was, she mused, a testament to the curious ways in which society often judged character, valuing proximity to rank above the more genuine, though less ostentatious, displays of true goodness.

It was a truth universally acknowledged, though not always readily admitted, that a young lady in possession of a tolerable fortune and a tolerable countenance must be in want of a husband, or at least, in want of the *appearances* of seeking one. Miss Eleanor Atherton, though possessing neither the fortune nor, in her own humble opinion, the countenance of surpassing beauty, found herself at a most peculiar juncture. Her aunt, the formidable Lady Ashworth, had declared it her earnest desire that Eleanor should attend the forthcoming assembly, a sentiment Eleanor met with a sigh that might have been mistaken for profound resignation, but which, in truth, masked a rather less noble apprehension: the dread of encountering Mr. Davies, whose pronouncements on virtue and good breeding, delivered with the unshakeable certainty of a man who believed himself the sole proprietor of both, were as wearisome as they were frequent.

It was a truth universally acknowledged, though perhaps whispered with a degree of polite reservation, that Mr. Fitzwilliam Darcy possessed a character of singular, and at times, rather inconvenient, virtue. His principles, forged in the fires of a considerable estate and an even more considerable pride, were as unyielding as the ancient oaks of Pemberley. While some might mistake his reserve for coldness, or his directness for insufferable arrogance, those who knew him best—or at least, who were fortunate enough to be admitted into the inner circle of his acquaintance—understood that his moral compass, though perhaps pointing a little too firmly North for the general taste, was guided by a profound sense of duty and an unshakeable integrity. Indeed, such was his adherence to what he deemed proper, that even a minor deviation from his established code of conduct could cause him no small degree of internal disquiet, a trait which, while admirable in its essence, occasionally rendered social intercourse with him a rather taxing, albeit ultimately rewarding, pursuit.

It was a truth universally acknowledged, though seldom openly confessed, that Mr. Wickham’s amiable disposition and ready smile concealed a disposition for borrowing, and indeed, for acquiring whatever might be had without labour. Miss Bennet, in her own gentle way, perceived this, not with the sharp acumen of her elder sister, but with a mild perplexity that such charm could be allied with such an evident scarcity of funds. She observed his dependence on the generosity of others, his easy acceptance of favours, and the rather too frequent references to past misfortunes, with a quiet sadness. For though she was no judge of character herself, she could not but feel that a man of true principle, however unfortunate, would exhibit a certain fortitude, a quiet pride in self-reliance, rather than a perpetual expectation of succour.

It was a truth universally acknowledged, though rarely expressed with any great enthusiasm, that Mrs. Bennet’s pronouncements upon the moral character of any gentleman were seldom to be trusted; indeed, her discernment, when it came to virtue, was as unreliable as the weather in April, prone to sudden shifts and most inconvenient sunshine appearing precisely when one had prepared for a deluge of disapproval. Her admiration for Mr. Bingley, for instance, though seemingly boundless, was founded upon so flimsy a basis as his amiable countenance and his readiness to attend balls, rather than any deep investigation into the soundness of his principles or the generosity of his disposition. Miss Bennet, however, observing her mother’s facile judgements, could not but reflect that such superficialities, whilst perhaps sufficient for a lady of leisure, were hardly the bedrock upon which true estimation ought to be built.

Mr. Darcy, observing the amiable but somewhat superficial discourse between Miss Bingley and her sister, could not but reflect on the alarming ease with which certain ladies, possessed of ample fortune and a commendable lack of introspection, could inflict their shallow opinions upon the world. While Elizabeth Bennet, though often playfully impertinent, displayed a mind of uncommon acuity and a moral compass that, he grudgingly admitted, pointed ever true, Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley seemed content to navigate life by the prevailing winds of fashion and self-interest, their conversation as insubstantial as a summer cloud, promising a shower of trivialities but ultimately yielding nothing of true nourishment. He found himself, to his surprise, yearning for the company of the former, whose very pronouncements, however critical, carried the weight of genuine thought.

The observation that Mr. Thorne, despite his amiable countenance and ready wit, possessed a character of somewhat questionable solidity had begun to circulate amongst the more discerning ladies of the neighbourhood, though naturally, it was uttered in hushed tones and with a great deal of discreet tutting. For, whilst his attentions to Miss Eleanor were undeniably flattering, and his pronouncements upon poetry and landscape painting remarkably well-informed, there was a certain laxity in his punctuality, a tendency to defer engagements until a more convenient season, that spoke not of a deeply principled man, but rather of one whose self-interest, however artfully disguised, was the truest compass of his actions. Indeed, one could almost pity the poor girl for being so readily captivated by a gentleman whose promises, it was feared, would prove as ephemeral as the morning mist.

It was a truth universally acknowledged, at least by those possessed of sound judgment, that Lady Ashworth's pronouncements on the moral character of her neighbours were delivered with an authority that brooked no dissent, nor, indeed, much consideration for the finer points of individual circumstance. Her ladyship, with a particularly severe tightening of her lips, had been holding forth on the regrettable absence of true virtue in young Mr. Willoughby, whose recent attentions to Miss Eliza Davies had, in her estimation, far too much of the *bon ton* and not enough of the domestic sensibility that ought to govern a gentleman's affections. One could not help but observe, however, that the formidable Lady Ashworth’s own virtue seemed to blossom most vigorously when there was an opportunity to cast aspersions upon others, a peculiar blossoming indeed, and one which, thankfully, produced no fruit to be gathered by the deserving.

It was a truth universally acknowledged, though seldom openly confessed by those who benefited most from the deception, that a young lady of limited fortune but considerable charm was often more esteemed for her agreeable manners than for the more sterling, yet less readily displayed, virtues of probity and discretion. Miss Eleanor Ainsworth, possessed of neither great beauty nor abundant fortune, found her own character subjected to this peculiar calculus by those in society who saw in her quiet industry and steadfast principles merely a lamentable lack of worldly artifice. Her cousin, the amiable Mrs. Davies, though well-meaning, could not forbear to sigh and remark upon Eleanor’s preference for useful needlework over the more fashionable accomplishments, whilst secretly congratulating herself on possessing a daughter whose skill at the pianoforte and lively wit secured her a far more promising position in the matrimonial market.

It was a truth universally acknowledged, at least amongst those with a discerning eye for true merit, that Miss Eliza Bennet possessed a remarkably sound understanding. Though her vivacity and a certain playful impertinence might have led the less judicious observer to question the depth of her character, those who knew her well, or indeed, who merely paid her the compliment of careful attention, could discern beneath the sprightly surface a foundation of unwavering principle. Her opinions, once formed, were not easily swayed by the fashionable follies or the transient opinions of others, a quality so rare in society that it might almost be mistaken for obstinacy, were it not for the evident good sense that underpinned every utterance and action.

It was a truth universally acknowledged, though perhaps not by all who professed it, that a young gentleman of fortune must be in want of a wife, or at least, a suitable companion to preside over his establishment, and that his prospects, however ample, were hardly considered complete without such an appendage. Mr. Woodhouse, therefore, with a diligence that would have done credit to a more pressing occasion, observed his nephew with a discerning eye, seeking not merely for traces of good breeding and easy fortune, but for that rarer commodity, an agreeable disposition, and a heart less inclined to extravagance than to the quiet virtues of domestic life. Indeed, the contemplation of so many young men, whose superficial accomplishments too often masked a decided lack of sense or principle, had rendered him particularly cautious, and he could not but feel a degree of apprehension that his darling Emma might, in her youthful eagerness to bestow happiness, overlook the true measure of a man's worth in favour of a pleasing countenance and a ready wit.

It was not for Miss Eliza to judge the depth of Mr. Thorne's affections, though she could readily discern the outward signs of a gentleman who, having enjoyed the privileges of good fortune, now seemed determined to employ them with an uncommonly serious disposition. His attentions to Mrs. Atherton, whilst undeniably proper, possessed a certain earnestness that might, to a less discerning eye, suggest an eagerness to secure an advantage rather than a genuine regard for her amiable, though somewhat vapid, conversation. However, Eliza possessed a keener insight, understanding that true virtue often masked itself beneath a reserve that could be mistaken for indifference, and that a man of principle would no doubt proceed with deliberation in matters of consequence, particularly when the happiness and establishment of another lay within his consideration.

It was a truth universally acknowledged, though perhaps not always comfortably, that a gentleman in possession of a good fortune must be in want of a wife. Yet, Miss Eleanor Ainsworth could not but reflect that a lady in possession of a discerning eye and a modest independence, whilst quite secure from the mercenary attentions of fortune-hunters, was not entirely exempt from the vexations of those who mistook amiable politeness for an invitation to endless discourse. Mr. Harrison, of Willow Creek, whose conversation, whilst devoid of offence, was seldom enlivened by any particular brilliance, had lately taken to bestowing upon her the full measure of his tedious opinions on agricultural improvements and the proper management of a parsonage. Eleanor, whilst ever desirous of behaving with becoming decorum, found her patience tested most severely, particularly when the subject of the parish poor rate was brought up for the third time in as many hours.

Indeed, the very notion that Mr. Thorne's pronouncements on virtue could sway opinion at Longbourn seemed to amuse Elizabeth to no end. She knew well enough that her father, while possessed of a most excellent understanding, was not to be easily dislodged from his principles, particularly when those principles so clearly favoured sensible behaviour over ostentatious displays of piety. His own discernment, sharpened by years of observing the follies of mankind, rendered him impervious to such superficial pronouncements. Mrs. Bennet, of course, had long ago adopted a firm conviction that whatever pleased her daughters was inherently virtuous, a philosophy which, though perhaps less rigorously examined, often led to more agreeable results. Thus, Mr. Thorne's earnest attempts to impart his superior moral compass were met not with conversion, but with a quiet, and to Elizabeth, deeply satisfying, amusement.

It was with considerable consternation that Mrs. Bennet surveyed her elder daughter, Jane, for the gentleman in question seemed to possess a most agreeable countenance, and spoke with a degree of intelligence which, whilst not entirely startling, was certainly a welcome departure from the general pronouncements of Lord Northington upon the merits of a particularly tasteless new carriage.  Jane, for her part, offered only a serene and encouraging smile, a testament, perhaps, to her inherent goodness of disposition, or, as her mother privately suspected, a rather alarming lack of discernment regarding the more pressing matters of establishment and fortune.  Still, even a sensible woman might concede that a young man of modest means and amiable manners was preferable to no gentleman at all, especially when the alternative threatened to involve yet another season of fretful idleness at Longbourn.

Miss Bennet, whilst acknowledging the undoubted propriety of her elder sister’s affections, could not entirely divest herself of a certain apprehension.  For Mr. Bingley, though possessed of a most amiable disposition and a fortune more than sufficient to secure the happiness of any young lady, was, by all accounts, sadly wanting in that force of character which is so necessary to resist the machinations of the worldly-minded.  Her mother, whose understanding, though frequently employed in the pursuit of advantageous matches, was not always the most judicious, seemed wholly unaware of the potential for distress, placing her entire faith in the gentleman's agreeable manners.  It was, therefore, a matter of no small concern to Elizabeth that a disposition so easily swayed might find itself at the mercy of a more determined, and perhaps less honourable, will.

Miss Eliza, ever possessed of a lively understanding, could not but observe the peculiar comportment of Mr. Ainsworth as he engaged with Mrs. Thorne. While his declarations of admiration for her embroidery were indeed profuse, and his solicitations for further details concerning the lamentable state of her father’s gout remarkably earnest, Eliza detected a certain theatricality in his earnestness. It was a performance, she suspected, designed to impress not merely Mrs. Thorne, but the entire drawing-room assembled. The truly virtuous, she mused, seldom required such ostentatious displays of their benevolence; their good qualities, like a fine silk, spoke for themselves without need of embroidery or embellishment. The ease with which Mr. Ainsworth navigated the waters of polite society, whilst so carefully cultivating the appearance of profound feeling, was, to her discerning eye, a testament to his considerable, if perhaps not entirely genuine, social accomplishments.

It was, to be sure, a vexing business when one found oneself obligated to acknowledge the estimable qualities of a person whose general acquaintance, one felt, had been pursued with rather too much eagerness and a regrettable lack of discernment. Yet, Miss Eliza's frank avowal that her previous admiration for Mr. Darcy had been founded less on an intimate knowledge of his character and more on the superficial gleam of his consequence and the general approbation of those who knew him not at all, served only to highlight a truth that many a seasoned observer might have overlooked. Indeed, for one so young, and so recently introduced into the society of her betters, to possess such a clear-sighted appreciation for the distinction between genuine virtue and the mere appearance of it, was a matter for considerable, if quietly expressed, congratulation.

The departure of Mr. Elton, though an event of no great consequence to the general happiness of the neighbourhood, had nevertheless occasioned a considerable stir amongst the more discerning, who, having for some time speculated upon the precise nature of his attachments, now felt their opinions quite vindicated. Mrs. Bennet, naturally, saw in it a fresh illustration of the folly of young women who did not secure their prospects whilst opportunity presented itself, sighing that Jane, at least, had possessed sense enough to refuse an offer which, it was now evident, would have brought her nothing but a respectable income and a tolerable companion. Miss Bingley, on the other hand, expressed a lively satisfaction that such a man, however genteelly born, should have been so clearly revealed as a specimen of vanity and presumption, and declared herself quite prepared to pity the lady who should next fall under his misguided attentions.

It was a truth universally acknowledged, though perhaps less frequently spoken aloud than the prevalence of advantageous marriages, that Mr. Thorne possessed a moral character of a rather singular nature. While his fortune was undeniably considerable, and his estate an object of envy, it was his steadfast adherence to what he deemed his own peculiar brand of virtue that truly set him apart. This virtue, it must be confessed, often manifested itself in a determined refusal to accommodate the slightest inconvenience, a trait which, whilst perhaps admirable in its unflinching honesty, did little to endear him to those who favoured amiability and a degree of yielding in social intercourse. His pronouncements on propriety, delivered with an air of unassailable rectitude, frequently left his listeners in a state of bewildered admiration, or, more commonly, a quiet exasperation that hinted at the immense reserves of patience required to navigate his company.

The Honourable Miss Eleanor Ainsworth, whilst acknowledging the inherent kindness of her neighbour, Mr. Davison, could not entirely dismiss a certain unease concerning his pronouncements on virtue. His pronouncements, so readily offered, often seemed to carry an implicit commendation of his own unwavering adherence to principle, a trait Eleanor, in her private reflections, considered rather too conspicuously displayed to be entirely unalloyed. It was, she mused, much like a gentleman who boasts loudly of his abstinence from gambling; one cannot help but wonder what temptations he must have so heroically resisted, or perhaps, more simply, what opportunity he has yet to encounter. His pronouncements, though delivered with a pleasing sonority, lacked the subtle introspection of true moral discernment, appearing rather to be a polished veneer applied to a perhaps less complex foundation.

It was a truth universally acknowledged, though perhaps not always acted upon with the same conviction, that a gentleman of modest fortune but impeccable character ought to find no insurmountable obstacle to a suitable alliance, provided, of course, that his amiable disposition was not entirely eclipsed by a want of advantageous connections. Mr. Davies, with his quiet dignity and a library of such estimable volumes as would have delighted even the most discerning of bluestockings, possessed precisely this blend of sterling virtue and unfortunate circumstance, a predicament that caused his friends to sigh with a mixture of concern and resignation. His understanding was keen, his principles unassailable, and his conversation, when it strayed from matters of estate and improvement, possessed a modest wit that promised much, were it not for the ever-present cloud of his limited income.

It was, of course, a matter of profound consequence that young Mr. Silas Thorne possessed an estate of considerable value, for such temporal advantages are rarely overlooked by a discerning eye, particularly when accompanied by a countenance that, whilst not strictly handsome, was rendered agreeable by a certain lively intelligence.  Indeed, Lady Eleanor could not but remark to her sister, in the privacy of their dressing room, how fortunate it was that his moral character, so lately the subject of much whispered conjecture concerning a rather unfortunate entanglement with the daughter of a local tradesman, appeared to have weathered the storm with remarkable fortitude.  That he could still command the respect of the neighbourhood, and indeed, the admiring glances of several eligible young ladies, suggested a resilience that spoke volumes, or perhaps, as some cynics might observe, merely of the powerful influence of a well-appointed carriage and a good tailor.

It was a truth universally acknowledged, though not always readily admitted by those most affected, that the pursuit of happiness was a remarkably capricious business, often leading one down paths as winding and uncertain as the country lanes around Meryton. Miss Eliza Bennet, though possessed of a lively wit and a disposition generally inclined towards optimism, could not help but observe how many of her acquaintances, in their earnest endeavours to secure a comfortable establishment, seemed to find themselves entangled in a most perplexing web of expectations and disappointments. To be content, it appeared, required not merely a suitable income or a pleasing countenance, but a peculiar alignment of one’s own desires with the often-unforeseen circumstances of fortune and the even more unpredictable inclinations of the human heart.
topic: The Pursuit of Happiness and Contentment

text: Lady Eleanor, a creature of refined sensibilities and a decidedly moderate fortune, often pondered the nature of happiness, a subject as elusive as a well-bred bachelor with ten thousand a year. She observed with a discerning eye the frantic pursuits of her neighbours, the Lady Ashworths, whose entire existence seemed dedicated to procuring the newest fashions from London and hosting assemblies of dubious merit, all in the hope of a favourable marriage for their eldest daughter. Eleanor suspected that true contentment lay not in the acquisition of superfluous vanities or the anxious cultivation of society's good opinion, but in the quiet appreciation of one's present circumstances, a sentiment that, alas, found little purchase amongst those who believed their felicity was to be found only at the end of a particularly dazzling procession.
topic: The Pursuit of Happiness and Contentment

text: It was universally acknowledged, though perhaps not always spoken aloud with perfect candour, that the acquisition of a suitable establishment formed the chief object of a young lady’s ambition, and that a truly contented mind was as rare as a well-turned compliment from a disagreeable relation. Miss Eleanor Ainsworth, possessing neither the fortune nor the dazzling beauty that might attract an abundance of admirers, found herself increasingly persuaded that her own happiness lay in a quiet and judicious management of her modest circumstances, rather than in the uncertain pursuit of grand affections. Her sister, however, perpetually sighed over romantic novels and the imagined trials of heroines, convinced that a life devoid of dramatic declarations and grand gestures was hardly worth living, a sentiment Eleanor privately considered to be the very height of folly, though she was too good-natured to express it too plainly.
topic: The Pursuit of Happiness and Contentment

text: It was a truth universally acknowledged, or at least widely observed in polite society, that a young lady in possession of a good fortune, though perhaps not yet a settled establishment, must be in want of a husband who could offer a suitable degree of consequence, and, by extension, a measure of happiness that mere personal merit could scarcely provide. Miss Eleanor Ainsworth, however, found herself in the rather uncommon predicament of possessing both agreeable looks and a comfortable income, yet appearing stubbornly indifferent to the most eligible gentlemen the neighbourhood could offer. Whilst her mother lamented her daughter’s lack of discernment, and her aunt tut-tutted at her unconventional tastes, Eleanor herself found a quiet satisfaction in the management of her own affairs, a contentment that seemed to elude those who pursued felicity with more visible, and certainly more fashionable, ardour.
topic: The Pursuit of Happiness and Contentment

text: It was a truth universally acknowledged, though not always readily admitted, that a gentleman in possession of a good fortune need not be in want of a wife, but that a lady so blessed often found herself in considerable want of a suitable companion to share it. Miss Eleanor Ainsworth, a young woman of modest expectations but considerable good sense, surveyed the assembly at Lady Croft’s soirée with an observant eye. Her own fortune, whilst comfortable, was far from sufficient to secure the attention of the more ambitious suitors, who, it seemed, measured a lady’s worth by the acreage she commanded. She could not help but feel a certain amusement, therefore, when Mr. Davies, whose estate was notoriously encumbered, began to pay her an uncommon degree of civility, his attentions as ostentatious as they were, she suspected, entirely unmerited. The pursuit of happiness, she mused, often led one down paths paved with the best intentions, but not always the most sound judgement.
topic: The Pursuit of Happiness and Contentment

text: Lady Eleanor, accustomed to the polished surfaces of drawing-rooms and the gentle murmur of agreeable conversation, found herself in a most peculiar predicament. The estate, whilst undeniably picturesque, possessed a disquieting silence, punctuated only by the wind's lament through the ancient oaks. Her sister, dear Amelia, whose own pursuit of happiness had lately led her to a most enthusiastic embrace of needlepoint, seemed perfectly content with the quietude, her days filled with the satisfying rhythm of stitch and hue. Eleanor, however, felt a growing discomposure; she could not but feel that a life of such placid uniformity, however virtuous, might be a trifle wanting in the very animation that made life truly worth living, a sentiment she dared not express too loudly lest she offend Amelia's newfound equanimity.
topic: The Pursuit of Happiness and Contentment

text: It was a truth universally acknowledged, though perhaps not always universally acted upon, that the path to contentment was rarely as straightforward as a country lane. For Miss Eleanor Ainsworth, whose days at home in Devonshire had lately taken on a rather monotonous hue, the arrival of her cousin, Mr. Davies, a gentleman of some consequence and even more amiable disposition, presented a most agreeable diversion. His opinions, delivered with such easy charm, and his seemingly inexhaustible supply of amusing anecdotes, banished for a time the lingering disquiet that had settled upon her spirit. Yet, even as she found herself smiling more freely than she had in weeks, a small, sensible part of her mind could not help but observe the subtle currents beneath the surface of their polite conversation; was this genuine felicity, or merely the pleasant distraction that so often masqueraded as such?
topic: The Pursuit of Happiness and Contentment

text: It was a truth universally acknowledged that a gentleman in possession of a good fortune must be in want of a wife, but for Miss Eleanor Ainsworth, the pursuit of happiness lay not in a matrimonial alliance, however advantageous, but rather in the quiet contemplation of her father's well-stocked library. While her younger sister, Marianne, fluttered about the drawing-room, sighing over sonnets and lamenting the absence of eligible suitors, Eleanor found a peculiar contentment in the dusty volumes that spoke of far-off lands and forgotten philosophies. She suspected, with a quiet smile, that many a lady believed happiness to be a matter of suitable connections and a handsome carriage, when in reality, it often resided in the most unexpected, and perhaps even unfashionable, of places. The rustle of Marianne’s silk gown, a testament to worldly aspirations, was to Eleanor’s ears less a melody of joy than a discordant note against the gentle harmony of intellectual pursuit.
topic: The Pursuit of Happiness and Contentment

text: It was a truth universally acknowledged, though seldom confessed aloud in polite company, that a person of modest fortune and considerable sense was perpetually engaged in a delicate dance to secure their own contentment. Miss Eleanor Ainsworth, possessed of the former and striving daily for the latter, found herself at a loss as to the precise steps. The arrival of Mr. Willoughby, with his easy manners and a fortune spoken of in hushed, admiring tones, had certainly introduced a lively cadence to her weeks. Yet, despite the flattering attentions he bestowed, and the agreeable company he kept, a faint disquietude persisted. Was happiness to be found in the prospect of a well-appointed estate, or in the effortless charm of a man whose affections, though readily offered, seemed to possess a certain fleeting quality? She suspected, with a pang of mild vexation, that the true pursuit might be a rather more arduous undertaking than the giddy flutterings of the heart might suggest.
topic: The Pursuit of Happiness and Contentment

text: It was a truth universally acknowledged, though often shamefully ignored, that a young lady in possession of a tolerable fortune and a lively disposition must be in want of a husband. Miss Eleanor Ainsworth, however, found herself in a rather more peculiar predicament, for she possessed neither the fortune that might attract a suitor of consequence nor the pronounced liveliness that might capture the attention of a gentleman of more modest means. Her contentment, therefore, had hitherto been derived from the simple pleasures of a well-loved book, the company of a particularly sagacious cat, and the occasional, albeit infrequent, witty remark that managed to escape her lips and land with pleasing effect upon her younger sister's ears. Yet, as the season advanced, and the dances at the Assembly Rooms grew more boisterous and the conversations at tea more pointedly focused upon matrimonial prospects, a disquiet began to stir within her, a gentle but persistent whisper that perhaps her present state of placid satisfaction was not quite the zenith of human felicity after all.
topic: The Pursuit of Happiness and Contentment

text: It was a truth universally acknowledged, though seldom so readily confessed, that a gentleman in possession of a good fortune must be in want of a suitable wife, and a lady in need of a suitable establishment. Young Miss Eleanor Ainsworth, however, found herself quite indifferent to the prevailing opinion, her heart being rather set on the quiet cultivation of her garden and the perusal of a particularly engaging novel, than on the grand manoeuvres of balls and assemblies. Indeed, the very notion of happiness seemed to her to reside not in the glittering throng of society, nor in the anxious attentions of eligible bachelors, but in the simple, steadfast pleasures of a well-ordered mind and a peaceful hearth. Yet, alas, such delicate sensibilities were rarely understood by those who deemed matrimony the only sure path to contentment, and Eleanor could not but observe the subtle, and sometimes not-so-subtle, pressures brought to bear upon her by well-meaning aunts and uncles, all eager to see her secure a fortune, and, by extension, a certain, rather superficial, sort of felicity.
topic: The Pursuit of Happiness and Contentment

text: It was a truth universally acknowledged, though seldom openly confessed by those who had experienced its sting, that a young lady's pursuit of happiness, particularly when tethered to the precarious fortunes of matrimony, often led her on a most circuitous and occasionally regrettable journey. Miss Eleanor Ainsworth, possessed of a sensible mind and a tolerable income, had hitherto believed her own contentment to be a matter of judicious choice rather than capricious fate. Yet, as the attentions of Mr. Davies, a gentleman of excellent connections and exceedingly bland conversation, began to occupy her thoughts with an alarming regularity, she found herself questioning the very foundations of her serene disposition. Was the quiet satisfaction of a well-ordered life to be sacrificed for the fleeting, albeit considerable, prospect of a grand estate and a husband who, though estimable, seemed to possess all the vivacity of a well-dusted parlour vase? The dilemma, she mused, was of no small consequence.
topic: The Pursuit of Happiness and Contentment

text: It was a truth universally acknowledged, though perhaps not always gracefully admitted, that a young lady in possession of a tolerable fortune and a pleasing countenance must be in want of a husband; yet, the true measure of contentment, as Miss Eliza deciphered from the hushed conversations and knowing glances exchanged over tea, lay not so much in securing such a prize as in navigating the intricate labyrinth of society with a discerning eye and an unruffled spirit. To observe the eager flutter of those desperate for advantageous connections, their manufactured gaiety and their sometimes transparent manipulations, offered a most diverting spectacle, though Eliza could not but feel a pang of sympathy for those who, through misfortune or a lack of worldly understanding, found themselves adrift in its less agreeable currents, perpetually seeking a harbour of felicity that seemed ever to recede.
topic: The Pursuit of Happiness and Contentment

text: It was a truth universally acknowledged, though perhaps not always acted upon with the requisite wisdom, that a young lady in possession of a tolerable fortune must be in want of a suitable establishment, and that the pursuit of such an establishment often led to the most peculiar contrivances. Miss Eleanor Ainsworth, possessed of an estate whose income, whilst respectable, was far from the dazzling superfluities that propelled so many into London’s glittering vortex, found herself observing this phenomenon with a detached amusement, though a flicker of wistful longing sometimes crossed her features. Her mother, whose own early married life had been a delicate dance between precarious economies and determined gaiety, was quite convinced that Eleanor’s future happiness lay solely in securing a gentleman of good connections and even better prospects, a sentiment Eleanor privately considered rather less profound than the proper management of her own small dairy.
topic: The Pursuit of Happiness and Contentment

text: It was a truth universally acknowledged, though perhaps less frequently confessed, that a young lady possessed of a tolerable fortune and a pleasing countenance must be in want of a husband; and the pursuit of this singular felicity, it seemed, occupied a considerable portion of Mrs. Bennet’s waking hours. Her daughters, blessedly occupied with needlework and the perusal of improving novels, appeared remarkably disinclined to exert themselves in this crucial endeavour, leaving their mother to engineer every eligible introduction and every artful conversational gambit. Oh, the trials of a maternal heart, when faced with such unseemly placidity in the face of matrimony’s manifold advantages! To be sure, Mr. Bingley’s amiable disposition and spacious estates offered a prospect sufficiently enticing to stir even the most determinedly indifferent spirit, yet Elizabeth, with her peculiar notions of attachment, seemed content to observe the unfolding drama with a detached amusement that bordered on the vexatious.
topic: The Pursuit of Happiness and Contentment

text: It was, of course, a truth universally acknowledged that a single man in possession of a good fortune must be in want of a wife; however, the same could not be said with equal certainty for a lady of independent means, who, though certainly in want of amusement, might equally find herself in want of a companion who did not presume upon her society nor bore her with tedious discourse. Miss Eleanor Ainsworth, having lately come into a considerable inheritance, had discovered that the pursuit of happiness was a far more intricate matter than mere financial security. Her days, once filled with the anxieties of securing a suitable establishment, were now occupied by a peculiar ennui, a gentle melancholy that even the most lively assemblies could not entirely dispel. She observed with a keen, though often amused, eye the various gentlemen who, sensing her newfound independence, presented themselves with an eagerness that bordered on the indelicate, each convinced that his particular brand of attentiveness was precisely the balm her solitary condition required.
topic: The Pursuit of Happiness and Contentment

text: It was with a certain resigned, yet not entirely unamused, resignation that Miss Eleanor Ainsworth surveyed the assembled company at the Michaelmas ball. Her cousin, the ever-optimistic Mrs. Davies, had assured her it was *the* place to encounter a gentleman of sense and fortune, a notion Eleanor privately considered as likely as discovering a unicorn grazing in Mr. Bingley’s park. The room, it was true, was tolerably full, and the conversation, a rather vapid hum of silks and speculations on the neighbouring estates, offered little distraction. Still, one could not entirely despair, could one? For even in the most unpromising of circumstances, a turn of the head, a misplaced glove, or an unfortunate allusion to the price of wool could, in the hands of Providence, lead to the most unexpected, and perhaps even agreeable, introductions. One merely had to possess the patience of a saint and the discernment of a seasoned observer of human folly.
topic: The Pursuit of Happiness and Contentment

text: It was a truth universally acknowledged, though seldom spoken aloud in polite company, that the pursuit of happiness, particularly in the marriage market, was often a most bewildering and circuitous affair. Miss Eleanor Davies, a young lady of good sense but limited fortune, found herself quite at a loss in this regard. Whilst her elder sister, whose affections had been most inconveniently captivated by a dashing but decidedly improvident ensign, had found her path to contentment rather sharply defined by familial disapproval, Eleanor’s own prospects remained a subject of much gentle, and sometimes not so gentle, speculation. The worthy Mr. Harrington, possessing an estate of tolerable size and a disposition equally devoid of fire and folly, seemed the very embodiment of prudent matrimony, yet Eleanor could not quite bring herself to feel that flutter of animation which, she understood from novels and observed in her more fortunate acquaintance, was the surest harbinger of a felicitous union.
topic: The Pursuit of Happiness and Contentment

text: It was a truth universally acknowledged, though not always acted upon, that a gentleman of good fortune, even one possessed of a tolerable estate and a suitably handsome countenance, might find himself quite adrift in the pursuit of happiness, should his inclinations lead him away from the comfortable predictability of a sensible match. Mr. Harrison, for all his professed desire for tranquil domestic felicity, had recently discovered this very predicament. He had, by his own admission, exhausted the amusements of his library, found the conversation at the local assembly rather wanting, and even the picturesque walks about his grounds seemed to offer less solace than formerly. He sighed, a sound indicative of a deeper disquiet than any mere ennui, and considered, with a wry smile, that perhaps the most arduous journeys were those undertaken in search of a contentment that, like a shy wild bird, might well be startled into flight by too eager a pursuit.
topic: The Pursuit of Happiness and Contentment

text: It was with a certain agreeable flutter, born more of expectation than true affection, that Miss Eliza Finch surveyed the ballroom. Mr. Darcy, for all his celebrated fortune and imposing presence, possessed a reserve that chilled the very air around him, making one wonder if his happiness lay in the meticulous arrangement of his estates or, perhaps, in the sheer avoidance of unseemly mirth. Eliza, though she privately acknowledged the considerable advantages of a secure establishment, could not help but feel that a life devoted solely to the cultivation of impeccable manners and the absence of spontaneous laughter was a rather barren prospect. Indeed, she suspected true contentment, that most elusive of sentiments, was to be found not in the grand declarations of the eligible, but in the quiet understanding shared over a game of whist, or the shared amusement at a particularly pompous pronouncement.
topic: The Pursuit of Happiness and Contentment

text: It was universally acknowledged that Mrs. Bennet had made a most judicious selection in Mr. Collins, not on account of any particular congeniality of spirit, though their frequent and lengthy discourses on the merits of Lady Catherine de Bourgh's patronage did afford her no small amusement, but rather because his settled income and the promise of Longbourn's eventual inheritance represented a bulwark against the gnawing anxieties that so often plagued her.  Indeed, the very thought of her daughters facing a future of reduced circumstances, or worse, the ignominy of depending upon the uncertain affections of gentlemen of inferior fortune, was enough to send a shiver down her spine.  Mr. Collins, with his steady mien and well-lined purse, was a veritable anchor in the tempestuous seas of matrimony, and if his pronouncements on parish matters occasionally taxed the patience of his wife, well, such minor vexations were a small price to pay for such profound security.
topic: The Pursuit of Happiness and Contentment

text: It was a truth universally acknowledged, though rarely confessed with perfect candour, that the pursuit of happiness often led one directly to the contemplation of a respectable income and a convenient estate. Miss Eleanor Dashwood, whilst entirely convinced of the superior merits of a contented disposition, could not entirely dismiss the evidence that a comfortable carriage and a well-appointed drawing-room certainly smoothed the path to such contentment, especially when the weather threatened to dampen one’s spirits and one’s muslin gowns. Her sister Marianne, naturally, found such pragmatic considerations rather vulgar, and preferred to believe that sentiment alone, however keenly felt, was the true key to felicity, a notion Eleanor privately suspected was more suited to poetry than to the pressing realities of supper and suitable alliances.
topic: The Pursuit of Happiness and Contentment

text: It was a truth universally acknowledged that the pursuit of happiness, though a noble endeavour, often led individuals into a labyrinth of social expectations and misplaced affections. Miss Eleanor Ainsworth, a young lady of sensible disposition and a tolerable fortune, found herself increasingly entangled in this very predicament. Her mother, Mrs. Ainsworth, a woman whose anxieties were as vast as her collection of lace caps, deemed the handsome but penniless Lieutenant Harrington a most unsuitable match, despite the evident tenderness in his gaze and Eleanor’s own burgeoning regard. Happiness, it seemed, was to be found not in the quiet contentment of a shared affection, but in the more boisterous displays of wealth and connections, a notion that sat uneasily with Eleanor’s more reflective spirit, though she dared not voice her dissent too vehemently, lest she be branded unfashionable or, worse, ungrateful.
topic: The Pursuit of Happiness and Contentment

text: It was a truth universally acknowledged that a single gentleman in possession of a good fortune must be in want of a wife, though Mrs. Bennet, with her usual keen perception of all matters matrimonial, was beginning to suspect that some single gentlemen, however well-endowed, might be equally in want of nothing more than a comfortable quietude, free from the importunate attentions of mothers with marriageable daughters. Indeed, the arrival of Mr. Bingley had initially filled her with an almost unbearable optimism, a certainty that her amiable Jane was destined for his favour, but his recent coolness, and indeed, his surprising preference for the company of his sisters and a rather boisterous gentleman named Darcy, was a vexation that threatened to eclipse all her formerly cheerful anticipations of domestic felicity. One could scarcely blame the poor man if his pursuit of contentment lay in avoiding rather than embracing the matrimonial fray.
topic: The Pursuit of Happiness and Contentment

text: It was a truth universally acknowledged, though rarely admitted with perfect candour, that Miss Eleanor Ainsworth, whilst possessing a considerable fortune and an amiable disposition, found herself in a most vexing predicament.  Her days, though graced with needlework of the finest quality and the agreeable society of her family, seemed to lack a certain vivacity, a vital spark that would elevate mere existence into true contentment.  She observed the cheerful industry of her neighbours, their bustling households and contented smiles, and could not but wonder at the secret of their felicity.  Was it in the dutiful management of their estates, the successful matches of their daughters, or perhaps a simpler understanding of the world's pleasures?  Alas, Eleanor’s own pursuit of happiness seemed to lead her in circles, a genteel promenade through a garden where the most enticing blossoms always remained just out of reach.
topic: The Pursuit of Happiness and Contentment

text: Miss Elizabeth Bennet, though she had always considered herself remarkably sensible, found her sentiments rather unsettled by Mr. Darcy's unexpected civilities.
