Miss Eliza Bennet, ever a creature of discerning intellect, could not but observe the earnest, if somewhat overzealous, application with which her younger sisters now pursued their studies. Their recent attendance at Mr. Collins's lecture on agricultural reform, though tedious to her own sensibilities, had evidently instilled in them a novel appreciation for self-improvement, a quality she could not entirely disapprove, even whilst privately noting the alarming intensity with which Mary pored over her Latin primers. It was, after all, a far more commendable occupation than lamenting the absence of eligible gentlemen, though Eliza suspected that a touch more of that particular observation might, in due time, prove equally beneficial to their prospects in society.

It was with a mixture of profound relief and a touch of self-reproach that Miss Eleanor Dashwood found herself once more in possession of her well-worn copy of "Principles of Botany." The very act of opening it, of tracing the delicate lines of the engraved plates and perusing the earnest, if somewhat dry, descriptions, felt like a homecoming after an ill-judged excursion into the frivolous. Sir John Middleton’s society, whilst undeniably cheerful, had offered little in the way of intellectual nourishment, and Willoughby’s charming conversation, though it had fluttered her heart, had ultimately proved as unsubstantial as a summer breeze. Now, amidst the quiet dignity of her mother’s parlour, she could pursue that most estimable of endeavours: the cultivation of the mind, a pursuit, she reflected with a wry smile, that would at least prove more enduring than any gentleman’s attentions, however flattering they might seem at the moment.

Miss Eleanor Bennet, though possessing a commendable understanding and a disposition generally inclined towards improvement, found herself perpetually wrestling with the formidable obstacle of her elder sister’s frivolous pursuits. While Jane, content with the gentle strains of the pianoforte and the latest fashionable novel, saw little necessity for deeper enquiry, Eleanor yearned for discourse that might truly expand the mind. It was not merely the acquisition of languages or sciences that she desired, but a sharpened perception, a more discerning judgement, and a capacity to engage with the world’s complexities, rather than merely to observe them from a comfortable, if somewhat limited, drawing-room. Her mother’s pronouncements on the matter, invariably centred on the desirability of a good marriage, did little to assuage Eleanor’s burgeoning discontent with such a narrow view of a woman's purpose.

The arrival of Mr. Davies, a gentleman of some learning and, it was whispered, a most agreeable fortune, offered an immediate, if perhaps unwelcome, distraction from the tedium of Mrs. Bennet’s domestic arrangements. Elizabeth, whilst outwardly attending to her younger sisters’ less-than-inspired renderings of ‘The Soldier Tired of War’s Alarms’, found her mind quite occupied with the various accounts of his intellectual pursuits. It was said he possessed a remarkable acquaintance with ancient history and could discourse upon philosophy with an ease that quite shamed most gentlemen of his acquaintance, who were generally content with discussing the latest fashions or the merits of a particular hunter. Indeed, the very prospect of encountering a mind that might offer more than platitudes was, for Elizabeth, a more compelling engagement than any ballroom assembly.

Miss Eleanor Dashwood, ever solicitous of improvement, found herself increasingly vexed by the conversation at the dinner table, which seemed to hover perpetually between the price of turnips and the latest county scandal. It was a lamentable truth, she often mused, that while gentlemen might discourse at length on agriculture and the merits of a well-bred hunter, the cultivation of the mind remained a decidedly secondary concern for many. Her own sister, Marianne, a creature of vastly different temperament, would, she suspected, find such a topic quite as tedious as Eleanor herself did tedious the tediousness. Yet, to Eleanor's quiet satisfaction, Mr. Edward Ferrars, whose own pronouncements, though infrequent, were always judiciously chosen, evinced a genuine interest in the intellectual pursuits she held so dear, a fact that rendered even the mention of Mrs. Bennet's ill-behaved children somewhat more tolerable.

It was a matter of some consequence, to Eleanor, that her younger sister, Marianne, possessed such an ardent disposition for the acquiring of knowledge; though whether this ardour was more directed towards the substantial improvement of her understanding or the more superficial adornment of her accomplishments remained, to Eleanor’s discerning eye, a point not entirely settled. Whilst Marianne devoured volumes of poetry with a zeal that might have rivalled a scholar’s pursuit of ancient texts, Eleanor could not but observe that the practical arts of household management, or indeed the proper cultivation of a pleasing conversation devoid of excessive sentiment, seemed to engage her sister’s attention with considerably less ardour. One could only hope, Eleanor mused with a sigh that was perhaps a trifle too audible, that the flowering of Marianne’s intellect would eventually bear fruit of a somewhat more grounded and generally useful nature, rather than remaining solely in the ethereal realm of romantic verse.

Miss Eleanor Dashwood, whilst professing a keen interest in the acquirement of accomplishments and the cultivation of her understanding, found her present pursuits rather less edifying than she had anticipated. The volumes of moral philosophy, though weighty in themselves, seemed to offer little practical guidance for navigating the delicate entanglements of Meryton society, and the French grammar, pursued with such diligent regularity by her younger sister, struck her as an exercise in futility when one possessed so few opportunities for refined conversation. Indeed, it was her firm conviction that true growth stemmed not from dusty tomes or rote memorization, but from a keen observation of human nature, a skill, she flattered herself, she possessed in abundance, though perhaps at the expense of actual, tangible learning.

It was a truth universally acknowledged, though perhaps not always spoken aloud with becoming candour, that a young lady of modest fortune but considerable spirit, such as Miss Eleanor Ainsworth, ought to employ her leisure hours in the cultivation of her mind. Indeed, her Aunt Marchmont, a woman whose pronouncements on propriety were as firm as her grip on her knitting needles, had frequently impressed upon Eleanor the necessity of acquiring accomplishments beyond the merely decorative. While Eleanor might have preferred the agreeable distraction of a lively promenade or the innocent amusement of a well-executed pianoforte piece, she found herself, with a sigh that was more of resignation than of vexation, poring over volumes of history and moral philosophy. The pursuit of knowledge, she reflected with a flicker of that characteristic wit which her aunt so rarely discerned, was a most commendable endeavour, particularly when it had the happy consequence of rendering her less susceptible to the tiresome flatteries of gentlemen who mistook intellectual vacancy for amiable docility.

Miss Eleanor Dashwood, ever the pragmatic one, observed with a quiet amusement the vigorous efforts of her sister Marianne to master the Italian language.  That the young lady should dedicate so many hours to the acquisition of a tongue seldom spoken beyond the fashionable assemblies of London, and even then, only when the company was particularly desirous of displaying their accomplishments, seemed to Eleanor a peculiar allocation of her considerable energies.  Whilst Marianne’s spirited pronouncements on the lyrical beauty of Dante might find a receptive ear amongst the more romantic natures of her acquaintance, Eleanor could not help but ponder whether a more thorough understanding of domestic economy, or perhaps a firmer grasp of French, might prove of greater practical utility in the navigating of this life, so often determined by more mundane considerations than the exquisite cadence of a foreign phrase.

It was a truth universally acknowledged, though perhaps not yet universally acted upon, that a young lady in possession of a good fortune must be in want of some edifying accomplishment. Miss Eleanor Ainsworth, whilst by no means deficient in the usual feminine graces, had lately found herself lamenting the rather superficial nature of her acquirements. Her needlework, though neat, lacked invention; her pianoforte playing, whilst technically passable, offered no profound sentiment; and her French, alas, was more suited to ordering a trifle than to conversing on matters of consequence. She resolved, therefore, to dedicate a portion of her considerable leisure to a more rigorous course of self-improvement, convinced that true elegance lay not merely in outward appearance, but in the cultivation of a mind capable of discerning true merit from mere fashionable pretense, a distinction, she observed with a wry internal smile, that many of her acquaintance seemed to overlook entirely.

Miss Elmsworth, though possessed of a generally amiable disposition and a tolerable understanding, found herself quite vexed by her sister’s recent pronouncements on the subject of female accomplishment. To hear Maria speak of French verbs and Italian sonnets with such an air of profound discovery, as if they were newly unearthed treasures rather than the dusty relics of a commonplace curriculum, was enough to test the patience of a saint.  Indeed, Miss Elmsworth could not but observe that Maria’s sudden ardour for intellectual pursuits seemed to coincide rather too neatly with the arrival of Mr. Atherton, whose own conversation was notoriously peppered with classical allusions and learned opinions. One could only hope, she reflected, that this burgeoning self-improvement was not entirely dictated by the desire to capture the attention of a gentleman who, by all accounts, possessed a fortune as considerable as his own conceit.

It was, to be sure, a peculiar sort of education that Miss Eleanor Finch found herself receiving at Mrs. Gable's academy. Whilst the other young ladies were diligently practising their needlepoint, their minds occupied with the finer points of tapestry, Eleanor, with a sigh that betrayed more intellectual ennui than romantic pining, found her attention wandering. The French phrases, meant to be uttered with grace and delicate inflection, seemed to her to hold less consequence than the subtle shifts in social alliances that played out daily within the drawing-room. She observed, with a keenness that would have served her better had it been directed towards her declensions, the quiet anxieties of those who feared falling behind, and the more boisterous self-assurance of those who perceived themselves already arrived. One might, she mused, learn as much of the world from observing a game of whist as from the most diligently compiled treatise on ancient history, though of course, such an observation would be deemed entirely unsuitable for polite company.

Miss Elizabeth Bennet, whilst diligently attending to her needlework, could not help but observe the earnest, if rather unvarnished, pronouncements of Mr. Collins upon the subject of female accomplishment. He declaimed, with all the assurance of one who had recently acquired a new set of pronouncements, that no young lady could truly be considered accomplished without a competent knowledge of the pianoforte, a passable understanding of French, and a flair for watercolour painting. It was a pity, she reflected with a private smile, that Mr. Collins himself possessed so little acquaintance with the accomplishments of true discernment; his own education, it seemed, had been more a matter of accumulating facts than cultivating the finer sensibilities, which, as she well knew, were the very bedrock of a well-formed mind.

It was with a degree of mingled apprehension and amusement that Elizabeth Bennet contemplated the rather vexing predicament in which her dear friend, Jane, found herself. Having received a most earnest, though perhaps slightly too effusive, letter from Mr. Bingley, a gentleman whose amiable disposition was matched only by his remarkable fortune, Jane was quite thrown into a flutter. While Elizabeth rejoiced in the prospect of her sister's happiness, she could not help but observe, with her usual keenness, the subtle interplay of hope and anxiety that clouded Jane’s countenance. It was, after all, a matter of no small consequence, this potential alliance, and Elizabeth, ever the devoted confidante, resolved to offer what counsel she might, though she suspected that Jane's own inherent goodness and Bingley's evident admiration would ultimately navigate the delicate currents of courtship far better than any pronouncement from her own discerning, though perhaps overly critical, mind.

It was a truth universally acknowledged, though perhaps not always readily admitted by those most prone to it, that the most enduring friendships often arose not from a shared passion for the same novel or a mutual disdain for the clergy, but from the simple, unadorned necessity of navigating the drawing-rooms of society together. Miss Eliza Ainsworth, a young lady of admirable sense though modest fortune, found herself increasingly reliant on the steadfast companionship of Miss Eleanor Vance, whose own prospects were far from dazzling, but whose spirits, it must be confessed, possessed a resilience that quite put Eliza’s own occasional despondency to shame. Their loyalty, whilst perhaps lacking the grand pronouncements of epic poetry, manifested itself in the shared amusement at the silliness of others, the discreet warnings of an approaching bore, and the comforting presence of a familiar face when the conversation turned to matters entirely beyond one’s comprehension.

Miss Eleanor Dashwood, possessed of a most discerning judgement, could not but feel a certain disquietude in observing the peculiar attentions bestowed upon Mrs. Jennings by the Honourable Mr. Palmer.  Though her sister Marianne, ever prone to enthusiastic pronouncements, saw only the most amiable of intentions, Eleanor perceived a subtle shift in their customary discourse.  A certain eagerness in Mr. Palmer’s inquiries, a prolonged dwelling upon Mrs. Jennings’ pronouncements, which, to Eleanor’s ear, betrayed less genuine concern for her well-being and more a carefully cultivated artifice, designed, no doubt, to elicit further confidences or perhaps, more critically, a favourable impression.  It was a delicate dance, this matter of social intercourse, and one Eleanor had long since concluded was often guided by motives far removed from the simple affection which she herself held so dear.

It was with a mixture of mingled relief and a touch of disquiet that Miss Eliza Bennet received the news of her elder sister Jane’s impending marriage to the estimable Mr. Bingley. While the prospect of such a happy conclusion to Jane’s long-endured affections was cause for genuine rejoicing, Eliza could not but feel a certain melancholy at the thought of her sister’s departure from Longbourn. Their shared confidences, the late-night discussions of trifling matters and profound concerns alike, had long formed a bulwark against the more tedious aspects of their domestic life, and the loss of such a constant companion, even for so joyous a reason, was not to be lightly dismissed. Still, Eliza possessed a resilient spirit, and she resolved to set aside her own nascent feelings of loneliness, focusing instead on the happiness that so justly awaited her beloved Jane.

It was, indeed, a matter of some consequence to Miss Eleanor Ainsworth that her dear companion, Miss Charlotte Palmer, should find herself in circumstances so decidedly less agreeable than her own; for though Eleanor possessed a considerable fortune and a most amiable disposition, she could not but feel a pang of disquietude when Charlotte, whose spirits were usually as bright as the summer sun, lately exhibited a melancholy so profound as to cast a shadow upon their pleasant promenades.  The cause, it transpired, was a perceived slight from a Mr. Harrington, a gentleman whose acquaintance they had only lately made, and whose conversation, whilst not entirely devoid of merit, often leaned towards a self-importance that Charlotte, in her usual good humour, had been rather too readily disposed to forgive.  Now, however, a perceived indifference on his part seemed to have pricked her pride, and Eleanor, though ever disinclined to meddle in the affairs of others, found her loyalty keenly engaged to soothe her friend's wounded sensibilities and, if possible, to discern the true nature of Mr. Harrington's intentions.

It was with a mixture of apprehension and the mildest of resentments that Elizabeth found herself compelled to accept Miss Bingley’s invitation to Netherfield, a place where, she suspected, her presence was more desired for the amusement of her hostess than for any genuine fellowship.  Still, to decline would have been to allow Jane the solitary burden of Miss Bingley's attentions, a prospect too unkind to contemplate, and Elizabeth, ever her sister’s staunchest advocate, would sooner endure a thousand tedious hours of condescension than leave Jane to face such unpleasantness alone.  She could already envision the veiled criticisms, the insincere compliments, and the general air of superiority that Miss Bingley would so expertly deploy, a display Elizabeth was prepared to meet with a spirit as unyielding as it was, at times, amusingly contrary.

Miss Eleanor Dashwood, though generally possessed of a most agreeable temper and a commendable understanding, found herself quite vexed by the recent pronouncements of her dear friend, Marianne. To declare one’s utter devotion to a gentleman of such fleeting acquaintance, and with such passionate effusion, struck Eleanor as bordering on imprudence, even if Mr. Willoughby himself did possess a certain agreeable countenance. Loyalty, she mused, was a virtue most admirable, yet perhaps best exercised with a measure of discernment, lest it lead to undue heartache. It was a peculiar characteristic of human nature, she observed, that the most fervent declarations of affection were often made by those least acquainted with the true depths and complexities of the human heart, and most susceptible to the superficial charms of outward appearance.

It was, of course, a matter of no small consequence to Mrs. Bennet that her eldest daughter, Jane, should form an advantageous connection, though she often lamented the quiet reserve that prevented Jane’s amiable disposition from being more readily appreciated by the gentlemen of consequence. Indeed, it was often left to Elizabeth, whose vivacity and ready wit, though perhaps a shade too bold for some tastes, served to draw attention where Jane’s gentle virtues might have been overlooked. Yet, when the affections of a worthy man were truly engaged, as they appeared to be with Mr. Bingley, it was not the surface sparkle, but the deeper currents of sincerity and constancy that proved the most enduring foundation for a lasting friendship, and, as Mrs. Bennet fervently hoped, a most desirable marriage.

It was, as Mrs. Elton would have pronounced with a flourish of her fan, a truly *vexatious* circumstance, that Fanny's intended departure for Bath should coincide so precisely with Colonel Brandon's sudden indisposition.  The very notion of her leaving whilst he, a man whose quiet devotion she had come to esteem above all others, lay beneath the doctor's care, was quite out of the question, of course.  Though her mother fretted about the inconvenience and the missed opportunity for some advantageous acquaintance, and even her more sensible sister confessed a pang of disappointment at the delay, Fanny found herself strangely unmoved by their lamentations.  Indeed, a peculiar satisfaction, bordering on quiet triumph, filled her breast at the prospect of remaining near the dear, invalided Colonel, a testament, she considered, to the unshakeable bonds of true friendship, so rarely to be found amidst the bustling and often superficial assemblies of society.

Indeed, Miss Eliza Bennet, though possessed of a lively spirit and an uncommon degree of sense for her years, found herself quite perplexed by the peculiar turn of events. Her dear Jane, whose amiable disposition was as constant as the sun's rise, had always seemed to find favour in the eyes of every gentleman of suitable consequence, yet Mr. Bingley's sudden departure had left her with a countenance far too subdued for her usual cheerful mien. Eliza, ever observant of her sister's delicate affections, could not but feel a pang of vexation at the indifference of such wealthy individuals, whose whims seemed to hold more sway than the genuine regard of a worthy heart. It was a truth universally acknowledged, she mused with a flicker of irony, that a gentleman in possession of a good fortune must be in want of a wife, but it appeared that Jane's quiet accomplishments were insufficient to secure such a prize without the further advantage of his own unwavering admiration.

It was with a mixture of amusement and a certain disquiet that Miss Eliza Bennet observed the unfolding of Mr. Darcy’s attentions towards her sister Jane. While she could not but applaud the evident sincerity of his admiration, a sentiment she had long suspected was brewing beneath his reserve, she also noted with her customary keenness the subtle anxieties that flickered across Jane’s countenance. Her dear Jane, ever disposed to see the best in all mankind, appeared to be grappling with a novel and rather overwhelming sense of obligation, an emotion Eliza felt was most unbecoming to the pure and unburdened affection that had thus far characterised their burgeoning attachment. Indeed, the very notion that one might *owe* a gentleman anything beyond a civil acknowledgement for his good opinion struck Eliza as a most peculiar, and frankly, rather tedious complication.

It was scarcely to be credited how deeply Eleanor felt the absence of her friend.  Whilst propriety dictated a certain restraint, and a lively circle of acquaintance offered ample diversion, the comfortable ease and ready understanding she had always found in Marianne's company were not so easily replaced.  Indeed, as she navigated the polite exchanges of the evening, observing the artful flirtations and the carefully veiled pronouncements on matters of consequence, Eleanor could not help but perceive the superficiality that often accompanied such social intercourse.  Marianne, for all her occasional impetuosity, possessed a sincerity of spirit that Eleanor cherished, a quality that seemed a rare and precious commodity in the present assembly, where so many seemed more occupied with pleasing the eye or securing an advantageous connection than with cultivating genuine affection.

It was a truth universally acknowledged, though perhaps less often spoken aloud than acted upon, that a young lady in possession of a tolerable fortune and a lively disposition, must be in want of a companion whose understanding was as keen as her own, and whose affections were as steadfast. Miss Elizabeth Bennet, possessed of both these desirable qualities, found her spirits much elevated by the recent arrival of Miss Bingley, whose conversation, though sometimes a shade too informed for general society, possessed a certain piquancy that delighted her. Yet, even as she relished their exchanges, a quiet observer might have noted a subtle tension, a delicate dance of expectation and veiled judgment, as if each lady, in their mutual admiration, was perpetually weighing the worth of their nascent acquaintance against the enduring value of those friendships formed in earlier, less discerning years.

It was a truth universally acknowledged, though perhaps less frequently confessed, that the most steadfast of friendships often arose from the most unlikely of circumstances, and that loyalty, once pledged, was a currency more precious than any fortune. Miss Eliza Finch, a young lady of sense and a tolerable fortune, found herself increasingly perplexed by the peculiar attachment that had sprung up between her former acquaintance, the amiable but somewhat vapid Mr. Davies, and the decidedly more astute, though alas, considerably less wealthy, Miss Eleanor Vance. For while Eliza could readily discern the merits of Miss Vance – her sharp wit, her elegant turn of phrase, her profound understanding of the human heart – she could not, for the life of her, comprehend what charm could possibly reside in Mr. Davies’s endlessly optimistic pronouncements on the weather, or his inane observations concerning the latest fashion in bonnets. Yet, the two seemed inseparable, their laughter often echoing through the assembly rooms, a testament, Eliza supposed, to the mysterious ways in which human hearts, or perhaps merely human vanities, were pleased to connect.

It was a truth universally acknowledged, though perhaps not always openly confessed, that the constancy of a friendship, particularly one formed in the agreeable carelessness of youth, was as susceptible to the subtle shifts of fortune and preference as any romantic attachment. Miss Eleanor Ainsworth, possessed of a discerning mind and a heart not entirely impervious to the enticements of consequence, found herself, at the present moment, contemplating the peculiar nature of her acquaintance with the amiable but rather unfortunate Miss Harriet Davies. Harriet, whose prospects had once been as promising as a spring morning, had lately been plunged into a domestic turmoil that, whilst eliciting the expected murmurs of sympathy from the neighbourhood, also served to highlight the rather less amiable tendency of some to withdraw their attentions when circumstances grew inconvenient. Eleanor, ever loyal to the dictates of propriety and good breeding, felt a duty to offer what solace she could, though a small, unacknowledged part of her observed with keen interest the gradual but distinct cooling of Mrs. Thornton’s customarily warm regard.

It was with a mixture of apprehension and a certain, dare one say, *maternal* solicitude that Miss Elliot surveyed the scene unfolding before her. Her dear friend, the amiable but decidedly less discerning Mrs. Waverley, was engaged in a lively discourse with the very gentleman whose recent indiscretions had caused such a stir in Meryton society. One could scarcely credit the ease with which Mrs. Waverley dismissed the hushed whispers of gossip, her countenance bright with an unshakeable faith in the innate goodness of all mankind. While Miss Elliot could not fault the sentiment, she could not help but ponder whether a more prudent discernment might not serve her friend better, particularly when such discernment might preserve her from the inevitable mortification that often attended such open-hearted trust. The loyal heart, she mused, was a virtue to be treasured, but even the most steadfast affection could be put to a severe trial by an imprudent acquaintance.

It was, as Miss Eliza had always suspected, quite impossible to truly ascertain the depth of sentiment in Mr. Darcy’s breast, save through the most inconvenient of circumstances. For a gentleman possessed of such substantial fortune and consequence, it was a rare occurrence for him to exhibit any great deal of feeling, and his friendships, when they did manifest, often seemed as rigidly controlled as his estate accounts. Yet, to see him now, so earnestly engaged in counsel with Bingley, his countenance betraying a genuine concern that far surpassed mere politeness, Eliza could not but acknowledge a certain, admirable tenacity in his loyalties. One might dismiss it as the obligation of acquaintance, but the quiet, persistent attention he paid to his friend’s evidently vexed spirit suggested a more profound, and perhaps more surprising, foundation for their regard.

It was a truth universally acknowledged, or at least universally whispered behind fans and fanatically defended in drawing-rooms, that a young lady in possession of a tolerable fortune and a pleasing countenance must be in want of a suitable acquaintance. Yet, Miss Eleanor Ainsworth, possessed of both in no small measure, found herself, at five-and-twenty, with a circle of companions whose chief merit seemed to be their steadfast refusal to discover any new merit in her whatsoever. Her closest confidante, the amiable but remarkably unobservant Mrs. Davies, would frequently declare Eleanor’s company to be ‘a perfect balm to the spirits,’ a sentiment Eleanor privately suspected was more a reflection of Mrs. Davies’ own flagging spirits than any profound insight into Eleanor’s character, though she seldom suffered the thought to darken her outward demeanour. True loyalty, it seemed, was a far rarer commodity than even a husband with twenty thousand a year.

It was a matter of considerable, though perhaps not entirely surprising, consternation to Mrs. Bennet that Miss Bingley’s attentions to her daughter, Jane, had of late diminished with a rapidity that quite outstripped the speed of a well-trained phaeton. Though Miss Bingley had always possessed a certain reserve, a coolness that hinted at a mind perhaps too occupied with its own superiorities to engage in the common courtesies of life, Mrs. Bennet had hoped that Jane’s amiable disposition and striking countenance might have, at least, secured a more consistent degree of civility. Yet, it appeared that the formidable accomplishments of Mr. Darcy, or perhaps the advantageous prospect of his proximity to the accomplished Miss Darcy, held a far greater sway over Miss Bingley’s affections than the genuine merits of any acquaintance, however deserving. One could only pity the lonely fate awaiting such individuals, whose hearts were so entirely given over to the pursuit of connection, rather than its cultivation.

It was a truth universally acknowledged, though perhaps less loudly proclaimed in country parlours than in London salons, that a lady of limited fortune and a gentleman of considerable expectation might find their paths entwined through the most unexpected of circumstances. Miss Eleanor Ainsworth, possessed of a lively wit but decidedly modest inheritance, had always supposed her most pressing concern to be the management of her aunt’s perpetually overflowing linen closet. Little did she imagine that her steadfast loyalty to her dear friend, Miss Beatrice Harrington, would soon place her in the unenviable position of observing, with a mixture of amusement and trepidation, the unfolding of a most delicate courtship, a courtship wherein the affections of Mr. Fitzwilliam Darcy himself seemed to hang precariously in the balance.

It was with a mixture of concern and that peculiar, yet not entirely unpleasant, vexation that Eleanor observed her dearest friend, Marianne, engaged in a spirited debate with Colonel Brandon.  The Colonel, a man whose silence was often more eloquent than another's discourse, appeared, for once, to be roused to a degree of animation seldom witnessed, his brow furrowed not in displeasure, but in a most commendable defence of a point of literary merit which Marianne, with characteristic ardour, seemed determined to disregard entirely.  Eleanor could not but reflect that whilst such ardour might be admirable in its passion, a modicum of deference, even to so esteemed an acquaintance as the Colonel, would perhaps contribute more effectively to the harmonious cultivation of genuine affection than any amount of spirited, though perhaps ill-founded, pronouncements.

It was a truth universally acknowledged, though perhaps not always openly confessed, that a young lady in possession of a comfortable income and a lively disposition must be in want of a companion. Elizabeth, though perfectly content with her own society and the amiable discourse of her family, could not but observe the particular satisfaction of Miss Bingley when she received an invitation from her dear friend, Jane. The very prospect of a fortnight spent in amiable conversation, free from the tiresome attentions of mere acquaintances, seemed to afford Miss Bingley a pleasure so profound that Elizabeth could not help but feel a touch of envy for such a steadfast attachment. Indeed, the world was often so arranged that the affections of women were tested by the shifting tides of fortune and the often frivolous whims of men, and it was a comfort to witness a bond so seemingly immutable, capable of sustaining itself against the vagaries of London society.

It was a truth universally acknowledged, though seldom openly confessed amongst such company, that Mrs. Bennet’s pronouncements on the merits of any gentleman were invariably coloured by the prospect of settlement, and thus, her sudden impassioned defence of Mr. Collins’s character, so recently dismissed with a disdain bordering on the vulgar, was observed by Elizabeth with a mixture of amusement and a familiar pang of exasperation.  He had, after all, made no alteration in his conduct, nor had his fortune undergone any perceptible augmentation; it was merely that a more advantageous connection, involving a certain degree of patronage from his patroness, Lady Catherine de Bourgh, had lately presented itself, and a mother’s anxieties, however ill-founded, are ever quick to seize upon any straw, however insignificant, that might float the prospects of her progeny.

It was a truth universally acknowledged, though perhaps less frequently uttered than its more matrimonial cousin, that a gentleman in possession of a good fortune must be in want of a companion, though whether that companion be a wife or merely a steadfast friend was a matter of considerable societal debate. Eleanor, observing Mr. Davies’s earnest, if rather clumsy, attempts to offer comfort to poor Miss Ainsworth – whose disappointment over a most regrettable elopement was, by all accounts, quite prodigious – could not but reflect upon the peculiar distinctions between true affection and mere politeness. Mr. Davies, she mused, possessed an abundance of the latter, yet his sincerity in offering his humble abode and modest library for Miss Ainsworth’s repose suggested a spark of the former, a quality far more rare and infinitely more valuable in the intricate tapestry of human connection than the most glittering alliance.

It was, of course, to be expected that Marianne’s impetuous nature, so often the cause of her neighbour’s gentle amusement and, at times, considerable consternation, would lead her to champion Lady Alston with a fervour bordering on the fanatical. Her friend, though possessing an amiable disposition and a generally pleasing countenance, had lately acquired a reputation of such dubious repute amongst the more discerning members of society that even Mrs. Bennet herself might have hesitated to offer unqualified praise. Yet, Marianne, blinded perhaps by the effervescence of a new acquaintance or the simple, unalloyed pleasure of a sympathetic ear, saw only virtue where others perceived a distinct lack thereof. One could only hope that the inevitable disappointment, when it arrived, would not prove too profound, and that her loyalty, so readily bestowed, might not be unduly wounded.

It was with considerable surprise, though perhaps not entirely unmerited, that Miss Eleanor Ainsworth discovered her dear friend, Mrs. Darcy, still harboured a profound admiration for the amiable Mr. Bingley.  Eleanor, ever the pragmatist, had long since dismissed such notions as fanciful remnants of a younger, less discerning age, and had endeavoured, with a delicate firmness that few could resist, to steer Charlotte towards more substantial affections.  Yet, the very mention of Mr. Bingley’s name, even in passing reference to his agreeable countenance or his penchant for cheerful conversation, would elicit a blush that was, to Eleanor’s keen eye, quite tell-tale of an enduring, if perhaps foolish, attachment. One could not help but ponder the vagaries of the human heart, how it clung to its first impressions with a tenacity that often defied all logic and good sense.

It was a truth universally acknowledged, though perhaps not always articulated with due gratitude, that while a gentleman's estate might offer comfort and a certain enviable consequence, it was the steadfastness of his friends that truly fortified his spirit against the inevitable vexations of life. Mr. Fitzwilliam Darcy, in possession of Pemberley and a considerable fortune, found himself, much to his own surprise, increasingly reliant upon the counsel of Mr. Bingley. The latter, whose amiable disposition often led him to overlook the more subtle machinations of society, proved an unexpected ballast to Darcy's more reserved and critical judgement. Indeed, it was during their protracted discussions, amidst the rustling silks and the clinking of teacups, that Darcy began to suspect that a well-meaning friend, however prone to occasional folly, was a treasure far exceeding the value of any inheritance.

It was with a considerable degree of consternation, therefore, that Miss Eleanor Dashwood observed her friend, Marianne, receive a letter bearing the crest of the notorious Willoughby.  Having so recently endeavoured to impress upon Marianne the delicate intricacies of discerning true affection from mere amiable civility, Eleanor could scarcely believe her eyes, nor the flush that instantly suffused her sister’s cheek.  Loyalty, Eleanor mused, whilst a most admirable virtue, could sometimes lead one to overlook the most glaring inconsistencies in character, particularly when the heart, ever the most unreliable of judges, was at play.  Still, she could not deny the genuine joy that danced in Marianne’s eyes, a joy that, however misplaced, Eleanor could not bring herself to entirely extinguish, though a whisper of caution remained on her lips.

The Honourable Mrs. Elliot, whose discerning eye had hitherto detected little to commend in her acquaintance, found herself unexpectedly disarmed by Miss Davenport’s unwavering devotion to her ailing younger sister. It was not merely the dutiful attendance, nor the constant readiness to procure whatever little comfort might be had; it was the genuine, unfeigned tenderness, a quality so rarely encountered amidst the superficial pleasantries of society, that truly impressed. Indeed, one might have supposed such a selfless attachment belonged to a character in some romantic novel, rather than to a young lady of such modest fortune and appearance. Yet, as Mrs. Elliot observed Miss Davenport’s quiet resolve, her own understanding of loyalty and the enduring strength of sincere affection began, quite against her prior inclination, to be considerably enlarged.

It was a truth universally acknowledged, though not always readily admitted, that Mrs. Bennet's pronouncements on the merits of any gentleman's fortune were as predictable as the turning of the seasons, and considerably less pleasant.  Her current fervent admiration for Mr. Bingley's estate at Netherfield, though ostensibly for the benefit of her five daughters, was, in reality, a well-rehearsed performance for the benefit of any ear within hearing.  Elizabeth, observing her mother’s animated discourse from the relative quiet of the parlour window, could not but marvel at the ease with which such baseless hopes were manufactured and propagated.  Indeed, whilst Bingley himself possessed a tolerable disposition, the singular object of Mrs. Bennet's affections seemed to be the ten thousand a year, a sum which, in her estimation, rendered even the most ordinary of men quite accomplished and worthy of immediate attachment.

It was a truth universally acknowledged that a gentleman in possession of a good fortune, though perhaps not entirely *good* in his character, must be in want of society, and that society, in turn, must be in want of entertainment, particularly when that gentleman was Mr. Silas Blackwood, whose arrival in Hertfordshire had caused a most agreeable stir amongst the eligible families. Indeed, Miss Eleanor Dashwood, though possessed of a sensible mind and a disposition ever inclined to esteem genuine worth, could not help but observe the particular fervour with which Mrs. Bennet, a lady whose anxieties for her daughters’ futures were as boundless as the summer sky, hastened to ensure her nearest acquaintance, the steadfast Miss Anne Elliot, was apprised of every trifling detail concerning Mr. Blackwood’s arrival, his estate, and, most crucially, his bachelorhood. For what greater assurance of a lasting friendship, after all, could one offer than the timely introduction of a potential spouse?
